title: Introduction to Philosophy: Values and Society
description: An introduction to the classical problems of philosophy through study and critical discussion of selected philosophical classics and contemporary works. Emphasis will be placed on questions of moral and other values and on the nature of society and justice.

title: Introduction to Philosophy: Knowledge and Reality
description: An introduction to the classical problems of philosophy through study and critical discussion of selected philosophical classics and contemporary works. Emphasis will be placed on questions of the nature and extent of human knowledge and classic problems about the nature of reality and our place in it.

title: Symbolic Logic I
description: A study of sentential logic, including translation, semantics, decision procedures and natural deduction followed by an introduction to predicate logic, concentrating on translation. Note: Not open to students with credit in PHIL 220.

title: Practical Logic
description: Elementary methods and principles for analyzing reasoning as it occurs in everyday contexts. Topics may include informal fallacies, introduction to scientific method, elementary statistical reasoning, elementary sentential logic, as well as the study of argument in contemporary debates about issues of social concern.

title: Metaphysics
description: Basic questions concerning the nature of reality. Topics may include existence, materialism and idealism, freedom and determinism, appearance and reality, causality, identity, time and space, universals and particulars.

title: Indian Philosophy
description: This course provides an overview of the ancient and classical period of Indian philosophy (500 BCE-1500 CE); major metaphysical and ethical concepts within traditions such as Yoga, Advaita Vedanta, and Buddhism. Note: Not open to students with credit in PHIL 302. Not open to students with credit in PHIL 301 completed prior to 2012.

title: Islamic Philosophy
description: A survey of the main figures and schools of thought in the Islamic world from the 10th to the 17th centuries CE.

title: Indigenous Philosophy
description: An introduction to Indigenous systems of knowledge as philosophical systems, which investigates these systems as parallel and coexisting with Western philosophical systems.

title: Philosophy of Mind
description: Basic questions concerning the mind and our attempts to study it scientifically.

title: The Human Person: Philosophical Issues
description: Personal identity, interpersonal relationships, sex and gender, freedom and immortality in historical and contemporary contexts.

title: Epistemology
description: A study of such central topics in the theory of knowledge as truth and rationality, skepticism and the limits of knowledge, relativism and the objectivity of knowledge, the role of perception, memory and reason as sources of knowledge.

title: Biology, Society, and Values
description: The philosophical and social impact of historical and contemporary topics in the biological sciences.

title: The Art of Living Well: Meaning and the Good Life
description: Philosophies of the good life. Topics may include integrated wellness, attentiveness, objects of devotion, and community in historical and contemporary contexts.

title: Symbolic Logic II
description: A brief review of sentential logic followed by an intensive study of predicate logic with identity. Topics include translation, semantics, decision procedures, natural deduction systems, mathematical induction. Other topics include: theories of definite descriptions, elementary modal logic, formal axiomatic systems. Prerequisite: PHIL 120 or consent of Department.

title: Ancient Greek Philosophy
description: A survey of the thought of the ancient Greek world from its beginnings with the Pre-Socratics up to and including Aristotle.

title: Trial and Execution of Socrates
description: A philosophical examination of Socrates' death in its cultural, historical and political setting.

title: Greek Philosophy and the Christian Tradition
description: Issues concerning human beings, knowledge, ethics and society among Greek thinkers and their impact on Christian thought. Note: Not available for credit with PHIL 139.

title: Descartes to Hume
description: A survey of Philosophy in the 17th- and 18th centuries. Philosophers studied may include Descartes, Leibniz, Princess Elisabeth of Bohemia, Spinoza, Locke, Berkeley, and Hume.

title: Medieval Philosophy and the Christian Tradition
description: A survey of philosophy from the 5th to the 15th centuries; Philosophers from the Jewish, Islamic and Christian traditions.

title: Contemporary Ethical Issues
description: An examination of questions of right and wrong, good and evil, and the application of ethical theories to practical issues.

title: Philosophy of Science
description: An introduction to the central issues in contemporary philosophy of science. Topics may include theory evaluation, paradigm shifts and theory change, laws of nature, causation and explanation, the rationality of science and its social and historical setting.

title: Moral Philosophy and the Christian Tradition
description: Analysis and evaluation of selected moral and social issues.

title: Political Philosophy
description: A survey of issues in contemporary political philosophy with attention to liberalism and communitarianism, sovereignty, feminism, entitlement and distribution, and global justice.

title: Feminist Philosophy
description: An introduction to feminist issues in current philosophy. Note: Not open to students with credit in PHIL 332.

title: Philosophy of Hunting
description: The moral, conceptual, existential, environmental, socio-political, and spiritual issues raised by the practice of hunting by humans.

title: Philosophy of Art
description: An introduction to some of the traditional theories, such as the expressionist and the formalist theories, which investigate the nature and function of the arts. The nature of aesthetic experience will also be considered.

title: Philosophy of Law
description: An investigation of the nature of law and of law's relationship to other systems of norms.

title: Existentialism
description: An introduction to the background and main themes of existentialist philosophy. Authors such as Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Heidegger, and Sartre are considered.

title: Topics in Non-Western and Comparative Philosophy
description: Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary.

title: Topics in Philosophy and Psychology
description: Central topics at the interface of philosophy and psychology. Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary.

title: Augustine
description: Prerequisite: At least 3 units in PHIL or consent of the College.

title: Philosophy of Biology
description: Core topics at the interface of biology and philosophy.

title: Thomas Aquinas
description: Prerequisite: At least 3 units in PHIL or consent of the College.

title: Risk, Choice, and Rationality
description: A study of the formal theory of rationality including probability and induction, and elementary decision theory, with attention to the paradoxes of choice.

title: Aristotle
description: An in-depth study of the philosophy of Aristotle.

title: Medieval and Renaissance Philosophy
description: A historical survey of western philosophy from the end of classical antiquity until the sixteenth century.

title: Contemporary World Views and Christianity
description: Critical study of Christianity in dialogue with such worldviews as atheism, agnosticism, naturalism, materialism, existentialism, feminism, liberalism, postmodernism.

title: Kant to Nietzsche
description: A survey of the philosophy of Kant and the 19th century. Philosophers studied may also include Hegel, Marx, Mill, and Nietzsche. Note: Not open to students with credit in PHIL 245.

title: Humans and Animals
description: Philosophical approaches to the question of comparative human and animal cognition, emotion, awareness, and language. The course will also address the problem of animal rights vis-Ã -vis individual and institutional human interests.

title: Foundations of Ethics
description: A philosophical investigation of theoretical questions about ethics, such as whether ethical values are objective or subjective, why we should be moral, whether virtues really exist, what role reason plays in ethical deliberation, and what constitutes the basis of our ethical obligations.

title: Environmental Ethics
description: Philosophical dimensions of issues raised by our relationship to the environment.

title: Philosophy of Religion
description: General topics in the Philosophy of Religion, which may include the concept of 'religion,' the existence of God, meaning and intelligibility in religious language, religion and morality, implications of the social scientific study of religion.

title: Philosophy of Computing
description: Philosophical issues arising from computation and computer science. No previous familiarity with computing is necessary.

title: Computers and Culture
description: Cultural, social, ethical and political issues arising from the computer revolution and new digital technologies.

title: Introduction to Philosophy of Mathematics
description: Overview of approaches to the foundations of mathematics and of philosophical issues concerning the nature of mathematical objects, mathematical theories and the special status of mathematics among the sciences and other areas of knowledge.

title: Topics in Social Justice
description: Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary.

title: Business Ethics
description: Ethical issues in business settings, dealing with such themes as employer-employee relations, job security, advertising, distribution of wealth, acquisitive individualism, the common good, and decision-making. Recommended preparation: 3 units in PHIL. Note: Not available for credit with CHRTC 394.

title: Philosophy of Sexuality
description: Ontological, epistemological, political and ethical issues arising through readings of classical and contemporary texts.

title: Philosophy of Disability
description: An introduction to philosophical approaches to disability.

title: Science and Society
description: A broadly based introduction to the intellectual, cultural, and social dimensions of science and their implications. Topics may include the impact of the Newtonian revolution, mechanism, materialism and Darwinism, and the nature of objectivity and rationality.

title: Philosophy of Criticism
description: An introduction to the philosophical foundations of art criticism. Questions concerning the standards of interpretation and of evaluation of the arts will be given special attention.

title: Film and Philosophy
description: Study of philosophical issues raised by films: distinguishing film from other arts (photography, theatre, video games), whether films depict or represent reality, emotional engagement, the relation of moral and aesthetic values, and approaches to film criticism.

title: Topics in Practical Ethics
description: Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary.

title: Ethics and Artificial Intelligence
description: A study of ethical issues raised by artificial intelligence systems.

title: Health Care Ethics
description: A study of ethical issues arising in health care and in the practice of health professions.

title: Topics in Metaphysics
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department.

title: Topics in Epistemology
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department.

title: Topics in Philosophy of Mind
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department.

title: Topics in Philosophy of Science
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department.

title: Topics in Philosophy of Biology
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of the Department.

title: Metalogic
description: The theoretical study of formal systems of logic. Topics include formal axiomatic systems, formal syntax and semantics, soundness and completeness proofs for both sentential and predicate logic. Prerequisite: PHIL 220 or consent of Department.

title: Modal Logic
description: Standard modal systems in sentential and predicate logic including possible world semantics and completeness proofs. Tense logic and epistemic logic may be considered. Prerequisite: PHIL 220 or consent of Department.

title: Topics in Advanced Symbolic Logic
description: Prerequisite: PHIL 220 or consent of Department.

title: Philosophy of Language
description: Selected problems concerning the nature of language and meaning. Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department.

title: Logic and Language
description: Philosophical logic and its application to the semantics of natural language. Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department.

title: Topics in Feminist Philosophy
description: Prerequisite: PHIL 272 or 332 (taken prior to 2006) or W ST 301 or consent of Department.

title: Topics in Medieval Philosophy
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200 level, or consent of Department.

title: Topics in Indian Philosophy
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200 level, or consent of Department.

title: Topics in Ancient Philosophy
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200 level, or consent of Department.

title: Topics in 17th- and 18th-Century Philosophy
description: Topics concerning the early modern philosophical tradition. Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department

title: Kant
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department.

title: Topics in 19th-Century Philosophy
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department.

title: Early Analytic Philosophy
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200 level, or  consent of Department.

title: Topics in 20th-Century Philosophy
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department.

title: Topics in Ethics
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department.

title: Topics in the History of Moral and Political Philosophy
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department.

title: Topics in Philosophy of Religion
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department. Variable content course which may be repeated if topic(s) vary.

title: Topics in Social and Political Philosophy
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department.

title: Topics in Aesthetics
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department.

title: Directed Reading I
description: Prerequisite: consent of Department.

title: Directed Reading II

title: Current Research in Philosophy
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department.

title: Topics in Phenomenology
description: Prerequisite: At least 6 units in PHIL, 3 units of which must be at the 200-level, or consent of Department.

title: Honors Essay
description: Preparation of the honors essay, required in the fourth year of the Honors program.

title: Topics in Phenomenology

title: Directed Reading I
description: Prerequisite: Open only to graduate students beyond the qualifying year.

title: Directed Reading II
description: Prerequisite: Open only to graduate students beyond the qualifying year.

title: Research Project
description: Capstone Research project required for and restricted to students in the course-based MA program.
